description: Paid functionality, watermark otherwise
Finally found PDF reader, which supports my documents. Not evince,not or..(KDE PDF reader), nor WPS office, nor Libre, nor anything else was capable to work properly with PDF. Thanks MasterPDF
Spend an hour editing an important work document, find out during saving IT INSERTS A WATERMARK. BAD BAD BAD!

The license is noted as Proprietary, which means you gotta PAY for the full un-watermarking version. You should have expected that before you downloaded it. Stick to open source Licenses if you don't want to be surprised like that!

I have one PDF form to fill out and send, so this is a one-off operation for me. Is the resulting PDF still able to use or is the Watermark completely filling the form in? Thanks.
P.S. I'd buy if I was using it regularly or daily, of course.
Not sure why people are complaining. If FOSS can't deliver a quality pdf editor, why shouldn't a company charge something full featured?
Very useful but not free to use.
Difficult to use
not great. this should be listed as a trial.

I have been using MasterPDF satisfactorily for a long time, always downloading the rpm directly from their website. This time however, I installed the flatpak version from gnome software (i am on Fedora 31). The flatpak version had the following issues for me:
- fit page to screen does not work properly
- masterpdf does not find my printers
- the recent files list shows weird locations (/var/run/....) for all my recent files.
Finally I decided to uninstall this version and reinstall the RPM downloaded directly from their webpage, and all problems are solved....
It won't saved to anywhere except to its own folder. I'd have paid money for it if it was worth it, but nope, it isn't worth a penny.

should not be posted as free. 
This company wants to hook some new customers.
really bad strategy
summary: how much is the license? water mark is Terrible

description: master pdf is best

coming form windows and bieng used to Bluebeam PDF which is a full feature rich PDF editor and collaboration toool, Linux was and is laking in the PDF arena; enter MasterPDF which is a great replacement for Bluebeam and a cheaper.

I know you have to pay for it if you don't want a watermark, But as I wanted a replacement for Adobe Pdf Creator on linux I was fine with that. Worked well for what I wanted to do. 

It was quick and did what I wanted. Design of layout was a bit more complex then I am used to but not really a hinderence.

In the end bought PDF Studio Pro 2019 as it had some more of the pro features I wanted and I could run it on Mac and Linux with one license since I use both for work.
You need to pay for save without watermark.

Some PDF readers have issues reading all PDF files sometimes they appear to deform at times this is a great reader, of course need to pay if you want to use power tools and there should be no complaining about price if you want great products for Linux this is top notch period...
Should be registered as a paid app !
summary: It's not freeware, asks the user for registration and leave watermark

description:
This is the only program I have found that actually is able to fill my sheets. This free version does everything I need. If it wasnt for Master PDF, I had to use Win10. 

Thanks a lot!
If you're doing a lot of .pdf editing work then it's really worth a license for this. Beats Adobe.
so much time editing, ending up with a watermark
summary: so much time editing, ending up with a watermark

description: This is great, I've been hacking PDFs about with it for about 4 years. AFAIK it does 95% of what Acrobat Pro will do. I know there's a lot of good FOSS stuff, but I'm happy to also pay for things that work, and this does...
summary: Not everything is a free lunch

description: THis is linux bruh, FOSS is the name of the game
summary: Got this just to insert a signature;Not included in the free version

description:
And yes, you need to pay for this commercial feature. Using Linux & OSS does not give you the privilege to ask other people to give you free stuff. 

This way at least you can sign PDFs on Linux at all.
summary: Literally the only PDF viewer for Linux to sign PDFs *omg*

description: You really want me to pay 70$ after I've spent one full hour filling in a very important form for my company before noticeing there is an enormous WATERMARK inserted in the final document ?.... To the trashbin, bye!
This application isn't open source anymore. It was at one point, but now it will slap a huge watermark on your documents unless you shell out 70 bucks, USD. I'm going to find something open source.
OCR doesn't work, exporting to other formats doesn't work, leaves watermark - It's infuriating that such garbage is allowed to exist in a Linux software repo.

Linux needs a PDF editor on par with Adobe Acrobat Pro, this is the closest I have been able to find. With a license, it does all the core things I needed in Acrobat: redaction - check (I like their redaction implementation); OCR - check (this is twitchy and doesn't hold the settings so you have go through thte OCR set up anytime you want to use that feature); working with fields, etc. And it looks like a relatively modern piece of software. Linux cumminity needs to get to a poace where they are willing to spend money on applications otherwise we will be looking for patchwork workarounds for Windows apps we need.
This my main pdf reader, even without license it does important task.

This application will cost you $75-$80 / year to use. Itś a subtle subscription model. Thatś why people that buy this software for work in Linux complain. They expect it to work in an generally accepted manner. They don want to have to relearn how to use a pdf editor. I have worked with adobe and Nuance pdf software and know there are standard, easier ways to create pdf documents. This software has a hard way to do simple things such as inserting text into a page. Imagine that, cutting a good section of your work space for an “Object Inspector” instead of allowing in place editing. Funny, they claim a banner to workflow. ´Itś a pity that just about all heavy lifting applications for Linux actually come from outside Linux, but thatś the way it is. One work around for those that find working with Master PDF a chore is to use the following option: if you at least have the following (unofficial) suite of productive apps installed: Libre Office, Xournal++, Okular, you will have much more to do and probably in a much easier manner.

Master PDF has many features, many are annoying such as the workflow busting restarts every time you make adjustments within the application. The mark and claim to a superior PDF editor is the functionality of its OCR engine weather it be traditional or AI.

Master PDF fails the test here. It certainly does not use
a good engine because it feels like itś using a genetic, vanilla-flavored, Linux type of engine. Its why it produces poor results.
The rest of Master PDF is just imitation of functionalities existing in other PDF editors carried out in a harder way. So, don't expect anything unique in its usability. Expect buggy performance under Linux usage. If you don’ t really do any heavy lifting with a pdf editor, then you might not see any problem with this software. And thatś just a fine thing, too.

jm
summary: My take on their claim to easy workflow..

description:
Do not, repeat, do not use an important pdf document to try out this application. It will leave water marks on the document that you won be able to erase with the trial application. Your document will be damaged-unless you buy their ware. Even then, there is no promise that you will have your document back.
Apparently, this developer did not think of this and many other things in
this application.´

The app is useless as an Adobe Acrobat DC substitute since you can not cut and paste information from other PDFs. As a stand-alone it would be fine. If you have to transfer information from one document to the next, though, this will not work.
But there is not a of support out there for pdf documentation. The watermark isn't too bad and you can avoid it by either paying for it, or use libre office for certain functions.
It's a great tool. I bought it a few years ago. It is available for Linux, MS and Mac. No Subscription like Adobe and others. It is not intuitive but has a lot of potential.
cannot be used as test and no way how to register - blocks all your docs. donnot install

You may buy a license and keep the installer.
The software asks for update and replaces your licenced version with the free version after one year.
summary: This tool is working great for me since 10/2018

description: Only usable when registred an paying, its no open source

The free version adds a watermark over the complete page, so only for testing. 

Use LibreOffice Draw if you want to have the same functions for free, PDF Arranger if you want to combine, crop, rotate or split pages.
Nachdem ich es gekauft habe, muss ich davon abraten. Die Software muss jedes Jahr erneuert werden. Ich hasse Abo Modelle.
I use this tool for many years now (I download it from the author's website, though) and buy a commercial version every few years. I really can recommend it for working with PDF!
summary: Best GUI Tool for manipulating PDF files on Linux

description:
Al modificar un pdf el programa añade una marca de agua a todo el documento, para quitarla hay que tener la versión registrada de pago. 

When modifying a pdf the program adds a watermark to the entire document, to remove it you must have the registered paid version.
summary: Few features in the free version

description: ... De esa manera se evita la molesta marca de agua

un programa muy bueno para editar modificar y corregir hace de todo en el formato pdf lo unico malo es que tienes que pagar por el para usar mas funciones y quetar la molesta marca de agua que coloca a todo el pdf pero a uso personal no importa
Decir que tener buenos programas también a veces conlleva pagar licencias y eso no es malo. Tiene un precio razonable para la envergadura de la aplicación. Funciona muy bien y es estupendo.
muy efectivo el programa

save options obscure places
